Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12 Grass Roots: Advancing Education in Renewable Energy and Cleaner Fuels through Collaborative Graduate Fellow/Teacher/Grade-School Student Interactions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI Name: Paulette Clancy
Institution Name: Cornell University
Proposal Title: GK-12 Grass Roots: Advancing Education in Renewable Energy and Cleaner Fuels through Collaborative Graduate Fellow/Teacher/Grade-School Student Interactions
Proposal ID: 1045513

Cornell GK-12 Fellows from engineering and the physical sciences are researching new ways to create renewable energy sources (wind, solar, geothermal and biomass) and other creative ways to reduce our carbon footprint. The core and strength of this GK-12 project lies in the development of new materials for energy creation and storage that achieve high performance and remain environmentally benign. The project will place graduate students in these fields into classrooms in grades 6-12 and will leverage strengths in creating computational tools to design new energy materials, predict their properties, and work synergistically with experiments, to accelerate commercialization. Coupled with their research, Fellows will undertake a new educational program for developing communication skills that will be highly effective with diverse communities and provide a life-long societal benefit for the promotion of science.

The Fellows will share their passion for energy research with students in middle and high school, especially those in Onondaga Nation schools close to Cornell. An early project, requested by the Elders, involves Fellows, faculty, and school students designing and building a solar (thermal) greenhouse as a hands-on project that fits a culture of earth stewardship. Many of the projects are strongly visual and computationally based, making them suitable for use by many communities, including students with hearing challenges, allowing their creativity to be fully realized. Fellows will enrich their research skills in energy projects, especially biofuels, through visits to a partner university in India, where they will take part in hands-on experience at a sugar mill where need for energy production must be balanced against that for food.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Roughly twenty-five GK12 Fellows from engineering and the physical sciences were funded to create fundamental and practical advancements in projects related to solar, wind, geothermal and biomass sources of energy, carbon capture strategies to mitigate the effects of man-made climate change, and improved materials for energy storage. The program created Fellows with impressive communication skills, precocious mentoring skills, and a deepened appreciation of their own earth-friendly energy thesis project, which they were able to communicate effectively to the public.

In the spirit of the GK12 program, all these Fellows received a specialized training program to improve their communication skills to allow them to effectively convey their knowledge of renewable energy-related topics to the public. This training involved a Cornell short course, and through close and lengthy interactions with seasoned K-12 teachers. Their ability to convey scientific knowledge to a nontechnical audience was put to the ultimate test by making typically 12 visits per year per student to K-12 classrooms in rural upstate New York. Not only did GK12 Grass Roots Fellows advance their own scientific thesis on energy-related topics, but we educated a cadre of PhD graduates with superior communication skills to convey science to the public, who have a strong passion for doing so. This new breed of STEM PhD graduates will spread their passion for communicating science to others that will be felt in the community for decades to come.

 

Broader Impacts: The major impact of this GK12 Grass Roots award was its profound effect on human capital. Beyond the education of Fellows, this award also trained twenty-four local K-12 teachers to personally undertake original scientific research. The importance of this reaches beyond the teachers’ own personal ability to appreciate scientific principles.  Critically, it heightened their ability to convey the excitement, creativity and ups and downs of science to K-12 students that a dry textbook can never rival. We inspired K-12 teachers, mainly from under-privileged rural schools. This program will have a long-term impact, thanks to the fact that these teachers’ strong positive influence will last for decades and inspire hundreds, or thousands, of K-12 students. The hundreds of visits by GK12 Fellows to these classrooms made science and math come alive for these children and the Fellows also served as powerful role models for science. Our Fellows reflected a strongly diverse group of Fellows in terms of gender and ethnicity, but also in terms of personality and presentation. Our group of Fellows may have sported a Mohawk, or a nose-ring, one was pregnant, one was older than their host teachers, some were exuberant showmen, some were quiet, some were fashionably dressed (geek chic).  But all were encouraging and approachable, and represented role models with whom grade-schoolers can identify. We hope they helped shatter the TV-portrayed and very limiting stereotypes of scientists.

We created roughly 20 educational demonstrations and lecture plans that any K-12 school nationwide can use. These educational products are available on our GK12 web site.

These numbers alone do not convey the sense of community in science communication at Cornell that has been formed as a result of this GK12 award. Each year, former GK12 Fellows actively volunteered to help new Fellows to be more effective communicators.
